text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> you are doing it again - flitting from one idea to another. If you were a baker there would just be piles of uncooked dough all over the place and not a loaf of bread in sight! Pursue an idea to completion before moving on to another sport. You've been given plenty of ideas and pointers of what direction to take. At this stage I will say that I don't think this slack is actually helping you at all - it may be that you are just getting too many suggestions. I would take ONE idea that has been suggested and logout of here for at least a week and work hard on that one area.

text: I agree <@UPMUFSGCR> but you don't buy a book, read the first chapter then start another one do you? MAybe the book is crap but you won't know until you finish it. It's a risk you take. You can't possibly know something is shite before you experience it first hand. I've said I spent ages trying to force MACD to "work" with no success. Maybe someone else has but I have no idea. Point is that nobody successful is going to tell him exactly where to look or what to do. I mean look at BFLW/flumine for example - I don't use it myself, but the existence of this is saving people literally hundreds of hours in itself. Not just the labour required to write that software, but the many additional hours debugging it so that people can now use it safe in the knowledge that it is reliable for the task. Fact is that it is not easy and spending a day on an idea before discarding it is not a route to success unless you get VERY lucky indeed. Just my opinion.

text: This is the trouble with trying to use purely market data and knowledge of how the exchange works. I've admitted to many that I am only in the green now because of the GPS feed. I still am at a loss as to how to price the market purely off the order book and trade history but I hope one day to get there. I've not worked flat out on things but I have been playing around with bots and the API since the mid 2000s. For me the only "obvious" way to get somewhere is through fundamentals. As a (former) mathematician, I am quite at home with the idea of using statistical models to spit out probability estimates using fundamental data but this is hard graft and is going to be close to impossible these days as a one man band without access to some bespoke high cost data because professional sports analytics is now such a big area. I can't say for sure why the modelling value from price action eludes me after so long. Could be just that I am not clever enough, could be that my brain just hasn't seen the alternative angle to view things from. My point is that there are no guarantees that you WILL become successful. Even if someone tells you the right area to look in, you still might lack the thought processes or intelligence to find the answers. That is just part of the landscape. Just because someone else is successful it doesn't mean you will be. Not meant to demotivate you <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> just trying to be realistic.

text: Already I am surprised by the results. I voted just fundamentals. Obviously I pay attention to what the market prices are but like you I struggle to see how to make money without a fundamental model. My advice to <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> was going to be that maybe he is another one for which price action alone is simply not going to work but the current poll results weaken that argument

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Just out of interest; would you say that the endless hours you put in on the MACD were wasted or would you say that you gained some benefit in being able to employ that knowledge elsewhere?

elements.text: Just out of interest; would you say that the endless hours you put in on the MACD were wasted or would you say that you gained some benefit in being able to employ that knowledge elsewhere?

text:
TLDR: NO

I think the biggest problem for me until quite recently (until I started dabbling in crypto tbh) was that everything I tried was based on traded prices alone without consideration of volume or what's on the order book. Groups like this slack were just not around when I started off and at the time I only know one other person who even know what Betfair was.  I recall one website <http://fred77.co.uk|fred77.co.uk> which was a forum where a few botters chatted about strats and bots but that was it. When I started I basically had tunnel vision - I wanted to use data to predict market movement over next X seconds and that was it. It never occurred to me that you could use market data to model value at all. So I looked at financial TA and MACD started to crop up a lot so I started off there. Obviously I widened my knowledge of software languages (back then bots were Perl and data was mysql) but I can honestly say that I did not extract anything useful from MACD, RSI, Bollinger bands etc. and moved on to US sports and logistic regression.

elements.text:
TLDR: NO

Groups like this slack were just not around when I started off and at the time I only know one other person who even know what Betfair was.  I recall one website
fred77.co.uk

which was a forum where a few botters chatted about strats and bots but that was it. When I started I basically had tunnel vision - I wanted to use data to predict market movement over next X seconds and that was it. It never occurred to me that you could use market data to model value at all. So I looked at financial TA and MACD started to crop up a lot so I started off there. Obviously I widened my knowledge of software languages (back then bots were Perl and data was mysql) but I can honestly say that I did not extract anything useful from MACD, RSI, Bollinger bands etc. and moved on to US sports and logistic regression.

text: Not at all but in listening to crypto traders talk about the markets the topic of volume was given much more importance than I ever thought it should have. Social media was not around when Betfair started up, whereas crypto has SO many active "traders" talking about TA and similar.

text:
Thanks <@UUE6E1LA1> thats interesting. I do think that peoples backgrounds and normal MO's do have a big part to play in this. Ive never used backtesting (until very recent) and although Ive not reached the lofty heights that some on here have, Ive been very successful.  Back in the 80's and 90's I worked on some very large computer systems and we were taught a process called kepner tregoe (I think NASA used it too), which we used in trouble shooting to define the problem before beginning to fix it. Some of the large computer systems had hundreds of modules in them and quite often you could spend many hours just defining the problem. I still use some of those techniques that ingrained in me even today.
I think if I could distil why some people are successful and not others, it is the way people see the problem and the task to be solved. They merely think differently

text: I think it's quite difficult to classify as fundamental OR price driven. I would say market prices/depth etc become extremely important if you pay attention to your execution, even if your triggers/forecasts are derived from a fundamental model.

elements.text: I think it's quite difficult to classify as fundamental OR price driven. I would say market prices/depth etc become extremely important if you pay attention to your execution, even if your triggers/forecasts are derived from a fundamental model.

text: My choice of going down the fundamental route was that constructing your own forecasts from exogenic inputs meant that you don't end up relying on some behaviour found in the markets themselves and hoping that the behaviour continues (given how people stop/start/trial strategies all the time, noise from mugs etc).

elements.text: My choice of going down the fundamental route was that constructing your own forecasts from exogenic inputs meant that you don't end up relying on some behaviour found in the markets themselves and hoping that the behaviour continues (given how people stop/start/trial strategies all the time, noise from mugs etc).

text: Lucrative is not the word I would use. I made a few thousand of the ERD->EGLD token swap surge and I did pretty well getting in (and more importantly) out after the late 2017 surge/early 2018 plunge. To be honest crypto is so sensitive on country specific FUD or bullshit tweets from CEOs that I only take long term positions now. I hold ETH, ADA and EGLD right now and nothing else. It's all profit so if it goes to zero I won't lose too much sleep.

text: I'm a bit confused as people use fill or kill often with an associated time delay but I understand FoK to mean place bet and fail instantly at point of placement attempt if the price is not available.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> What you're referring to is Betfair's API implementation of FOK, but I believe it's poor for some reason or another, so most people in here use a short time if say 0.5sec instead. I'm sure someone will correct me if I'm talking bollocks. :joy:

elements.text: What you're referring to is Betfair's API implementation of FOK, but I believe it's poor for some reason or another, so most people in here use a short time if say 0.5sec instead. I'm sure someone will correct me if I'm talking bollocks.

text: By definition, cancelling after any kind of delay is not fill or kill

elements.text: By definition, cancelling after any kind of delay is not fill or kill

text: The problem with how its been implemented in the Betfair API is you can be filled at prices below what you request provided your average price is as good or better than what you requested. This means you can get some negative EV junk thrown in which you avoid if you handle the cancellation yourself

elements.text: The problem with how its been implemented in the Betfair API is you can be filled at prices below what you request provided your average price is as good or better than what you requested. This means you can get some negative EV junk thrown in which you avoid if you handle the cancellation yourself

text: Yeah I have implemented it and used to use it before many discussions here similar to the above by <@UBS7QANF3> that is why I am confused as to my mind it you place a bet WITHOUT the fill or kill mechanism, it is not a fill or kill bet - its just a short lifetime bet based on your own applied rules/monitoring.
